hydro_db.py¶

Module to load hydrodynamic BEM data from Nemoh code

class HydroDB.hydro_db.HydroBody(ibody, mesh)[source]¶

Bases: object

Class to represent a hydrodynamic body

It is used to represent a hydrodynamic body that is used in BEM computations. This class is mainly here to enclose integration and radiation modes on a per body fashion.

class HydroDB.hydro_db.HydroDB[source]¶

Bases: HydroDB.hydro_db._FreqDB

class to store frequency dependent hydrodynamics data coming from BEM codes in frequency domain.

rho_water¶

density of water (kg/m**3). Default is 1000 kg/m**3

Type:float
grav¶

acceleration of the gravity field. Default is 9.81 m/s**2

Type:float
depth¶

local water depth in m. Default is inf, meaning an infinite water depth.

Type:float
x_wave_measure¶

x position of the wave probe used for wave elevation

Type:float
y_wave_measure¶

y position of the wave probe used for wave elevation

Type:float
nb_wave_dir¶

Number of wave directions used in computations

Type:int
min_wave_dir¶
Type:float
diffraction_db¶
froude_krylov_db¶
nb_bem_problems¶

Total number of problems solved during the BEM computations

It is nw * (ntheta + nradiation)

Returns:
Return type:int

class HydroDB.hydro_db.NemohBEMData[source]¶

Bases: object

Class to manage a Hydrodynamic database for several bodies

At that moment, it only deals with 1st order hydrodynamics but in the future, it should also deal with second order (mean drift, QTF)

dirname¶

The root directory where the BEM computations have taken place

Type:str
rho_water¶

Water density (kg/m**3)

Type:float
grav¶

Gravity acceleration (m/s**2)

Type:float
depth¶

Water depth (meters)

Type:float
x_wave_measure¶

x position of free surface elevation measure

Type:float
y_wave_measure¶

y position of free surface elevation measure

Type:float
nb_frequencies¶

Number of frequency discretization in BEM computations

Type:int
min_frequency¶

Min frequency (rad/s) of frequency discretization. Should usually not be 0.

Type:float
max_frequency¶

Max frequency of frequency (rad/s) discretization.

Type:float
nb_wave_directions¶

Number of wave directions in BEM computations

Type:int
min_wave_dir¶

Min wave direction (deg) of waves

Type:float
max_wave_dir¶

Max wave direction (def) of waves

Type:float
diffraction¶

(nb_force_modes x nb_frequencies x nb_motion_modes) complex numbers array of wave diffraction coefficients

Type:np.array
added_mass¶

(nb_force_modes x nb_frequencies x nb_motion_modes) array of added mass coefficients

Type:np.ndarray
radiation_damping¶

(nb_force_modes x nb_frequencies x nb_motion_modes) array of radiation damping coefficients

Type:np.ndarray
radiation_flags¶

(nb_force_modes x nb_motion_mods) boolean array of hydrodynamic modes that are significant (True if significant)

Type:np.ndarray
_irf¶

Impulse response functions of the system

Type:RadiationIRFDB
dt_irf¶

Time step to take to compute impulse response functions (seconds)

Type:float
tf_irf¶

Final time to take to compute impulse response functions (seconds)

Type:float
has_kochin¶

True if we load Kochin functions

Type:bool
kochin_radiation¶

(nb_motion_modes x nb_frequencies x nb_dir_kochin) complex array of Kochin functions for radiation modes

Type:np.ndarray
kochin_diffraction¶

(nb_wave_dir x nb_frequencies x nb_dir_kochin) complex array of Kochin functions for diffraction modes

Type:np.ndarray
nb_dir_kochin¶

Number of directions used to evaluate Kochin functions

Type:int
min_dir_kochin¶

Min angle (deg) used to evaluate Kochin functions

Type:float
max_dir_kochin¶

Max angle (deg) used to evaluate Kochin functions

Type:float
free_surface¶

Not used

Type:np.ndarray
nx_fs¶

Not used

Type:int
ny_fs¶

Not used

Type:int
xlim_fs¶

Not used

Type:float
ylim_fs¶

Not used

Type:float
bodies¶

List of HydroBody objects taken in BEM computations

Type:list
Note¶
-----
Instanciate the method and just load Nemoh computations using the set_calulation_file('Nemoh.cal') method.
fs_grid¶

Grid taken to compute the free surface elevation from BEM computations

Returns:A tuple abtained by meshgrid
Return type:np.ndarray, np.ndarray
kochin_directions¶

Angles array taken for Kochin functions computations

Returns:angles array in radians
Return type:np.ndarray
class HydroDB.hydro_db.RadiationDB[source]¶

Bases: HydroDB.hydro_db._FreqDB

Class to hold hydrodynamic radiation coefficients

Parameters:
  • wmin (float) – Minimum angular frequency (rad/s)
  • wmax (float) – Maximum angular frequency (rad/s)
  • nw (int) – Number of frequency samples
  • ca (array_like) – array of radiation damping coefficients samples
  • cm (array_like) – array of radiation added mass coefficients samples
  • bodies (list) – List of HydroBody objects involved in the hydrodynamic model
  • cm_inf (array_like, optional) – array of infinite frequency added mass coefficients
added_mass¶
clean()[source]¶
eval_impulse_response_function(tf=30.0, dt=None, full=True)[source]¶

Computes the impulse response function

It uses the Ogilvie formulas based on radiation damping integration (Inverse Fourier Transform)

Parameters:
  • tf (float, optional) – Final time (seconds). Default is 30.
  • dt (float, optional) – Time step (seconds). Default is None. If None, a time step is computed according to the max frequency of hydrodynamic coefficients (the Nyquist frequency is taken)
  • full (bool, optional) – If True (default), it will use the full frequency range for computations.
Returns:

Radiation Impulse Response Database object
Return type:

RadiationIRFDB
eval_impulse_response_function_Ku(tf=30.0, dt=None, full=True)[source]¶

Computes the impulse response function relative to the ship advance speed

ref : F. Rongère et al. (Journées de l’Hydrodynamique 2010 - Nantes)

Parameters:
  • tf (float, optional) – Final time (seconds). Default is 30.
  • dt (float, optional) – Time step (seconds). Default is None. If None, a time step is computed according to the max frequency of hydrodynamic coefficients (the Nyquist frequency is taken)
  • full (bool, optional) – If True (default), it will use the full frequency range for computations.
Returns:

Radiation Impulse Response Database object
Return type:

RadiationIRFDB
eval_infinite_added_mass(full=True)[source]¶

Evaluates the infinite added mass matrix coefficients using Ogilvie formula.

Parameters:full (bool, optional) –

If True (default), it will use the full frequency range for computations.

It uses the Ogilvie formula to get the coefficients from the impulse response functions
flags¶
frequency_response¶

Returns the complex radiation frequency response (radiation transfer function)

This is K(jw) = CA(w) + jw(CM(w)-CMinf). It is to be used in identification procedures

Returns:(nb_force_modes x nb_frequencies x nb_motion_modes) Complex array of radiation frequency responses
Return type:np.ndarray

  • iforce (int) – Index of the local body’s force mode

Complex array of radiation frequency response
Return type:

np.ndarray
get_infinite_added_mass_matrix(ibody_force=None, ibody_motion=None)[source]¶

Get the infinite added mass matrix for forces on one body and motions of a possibly other body

Parameters:
  • ibody_force (int, optional) – Index of body on which radiation forces applies. If None (default), every lines of the system will be taken
  • ibody_motion (int, optional) – Index of body that performs motions. If None (default), every degree of freedom of the system will be taken
Returns:
Return type:

np.ndarray

Notes

  • It both index are used and are equal, the ‘pure’ added mass matrix of a body is returned
  • If both index are used but are different, coupling matrices are returned
  • If only the first index is given, then lines of the returned matrix correspond to forces on the corresponding body but columns concern every degree of freedom of the system
  • If only the second index is given, then lines of the returned matrix concern forces on every body of the structure but columns only concern the degree of freedom of the specified body

get_body_data(ibody)[source]¶
get_complex_coeffs(ibody, iforce, iwave=0)[source]¶

Get the diffraction coefficients for a body’s mode and a given wave direction

Parameters:
  • ibody (int) – The index of the body
  • iforce (int) – The index of the wanted body’s integration mode
  • iwave (int, float) – Wave direction. If an int is given, it is used as an index in the wave_dir array. If a float is given, the closest wave direction is given
Returns:

Complex array of the diffraction coefficients
Return type:

np.ndarray
get_wave_measure_position()[source]¶
interp(omega, wave_dir, ibody=None, unit='deg')[source]¶

Interpolate wave excitation hydrodynamic coefficient over frequency and wave directions

Parameters:
  • omega (np.ndarray) – angular frequencies at which the database has to be interpolated
  • wave_dir (np.ndarray) – wave directions at which the database has to be interpolated
  • ibody (int, optional) – The id of the hydrodynamic body in the database. If None (default), the full results for every bodies in interaction will be interpolated
  • = 'str', optional (unit) – The angle unit used in wave_dir. Default is ‘deg’. May also be ‘rad’
Returns:

Complex array of hydrodynamic coefficients interpolated at requested places.
Return type:

np.ndarray[complex]
Raises:

Error if the requested values are outside the ranges of the database

Notes

Interpolation in database allows to set a linear wavefield with a different discretization than the database. It is of practical usage when the database has been realized with numerous values so that it covers the broader range of simulations but are over-discretized with respect to the needs in excitation force computations as they would give a too computational demanding double sum.

plot(ibody, iforce, iwave=0, **kwargs)[source]¶

Plots the diffraction response function of a given modes set

Parameters:
  • ibody (int) – The index of the body
  • iforce (int) – The index of the body’s force mode
  • iwave (int, float) – The index of the wave direction (if an integer is given) or the value of the wave_direction in degrees in a float is given. In the latter case, the most close angle is taken (not necessarily the one that is given here…)
  • kwargs (optional) – Arguments that are to be used by pyplot
